prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We tune our four basebands to the SiO(8-7), CH3OH(4-3), CO(3-2), and HCO+(4-3) lines which address our main science goals. Our narrowest resulting spectral window is 1660 km/s wide which is well over the coverage we need to detect our emission lines. SiO and CH3OH have been observed in other galaxies (Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with line widths as low as 15 km/s. Even the CO(1-0) line (observed at ~400 km/s) would be Nyquist sampled in a 1660 km/s-wide band.

To enable a comparison of the distribution of molecular gas as revealed by ALMA to star clusters seen in our HST imaging, we require spatial resolutions of 0.22". The LIRG disk does not appear to extend beyond the largest recoverable scale and so we do not require the ACA.

Our goal is to map the luminous IR galaxy ESO507-G030 in CO(3-2), HCO+(4-3), SiO, and CH3OH. A total CO(3-2) flux and line width from the JCMT are available in the literature (43.8 K km/s and 479 km/s; Leech et al. 2010). If the gas distribution we are probing with ALMA is spread out (i.e. divided over ten clumps or beams) and we desire a signal-to-noise of 6, our sensitivity requirement is an rms of 22.5 mJy. There are also single-dish measurements of the CO(1-0) flux for this LIRG (142.0 Jy km/s and w~400 km/s; Mirabel et al. 1990). For a sample of nearby U/LIRGs, Wilson et al. (2008) found ratios of HCO+(4-3)/CO(1-0) of ~0.1-0.2 which conservatively translates to a sensitivity requirement of 2.8 mJy for detecting the HCO+(4-3) line at a signal-to-noise of 6 for multiple (2) clumps. Both observations (Meier & Turner 2012) and simulations (Meijerink & Israel 2007) of SiO in nearby galaxies suggest SiO(1-0)/CO(1-0) ~ 0.05-0.1, as well as an agreement within the SiO and methanol lines (at a given transition within an order of magnitude. Thus we expect both the SiO and CH3OH fluxes to be on the order of half of that of HCO+(4-3) and thus easily detected.
SiO and CH3OH lines have been observed in other galaxies (i.e. Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with linewidths as low as 15 km/s, so we require 5 km/s spectral resolution to Nyquist sample the line.

We tune our four basebands to the SiO(8-7), CH3OH(4-3), CO(3-2), and HCO+(4-3) lines which address our main science goals. Our narrowest resulting spectral window is 1660 km/s wide which is well over the coverage we need to detect our emission lines. SiO and CH3OH have been observed in other galaxies (Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with line widths as low as 15 km/s. Even the CO(1-0) line (observed at ~400 km/s) would be Nyquist sampled in a 1660 km/s-wide band.

To enable a comparison of the distribution of molecular gas as revealed by ALMA to star clusters seen in our HST imaging, we require spatial resolutions of 0.22". The LIRG disk does not appear to extend beyond the largest recoverable scale and so we do not require the ACA.

Our goal is to map the luminous IR galaxy IRAS01364-1042 in CO(3-2), HCO+(4-3), SiO, and CH3OH. No CO(3-2) fluxes are available in the literature, so we use the published CO(1-0) flux and line width (46.5 Jy km/s, w~80 km/s; Mirabel et al. 1990) and an average conversion ratio quoted for LIRGs of R31~0.5 (Leech et al. 2020; Papadapolous et al. 2008), to estimate the total CO(3-2) flux. Assuming a Gaussian line, we expect peak fluxes of 2.47 Jy for CO(3-2). If the gas distribution we are probing with ALMA is spread out (i.e. divided over ten clumps or beams) and we desire a signal-to-noise of 6, our sensitivity requirement is an rms of 41.2 mJy.
For a sample of nearby U/LIRGs, Wilson et al. (2008) found ratios of HCO+(4-3)/CO(1-0) of ~0.1-0.2 which conservatively translates to a sensitivity requirement of 3.1 mJy for detecting the HCO+(4-3) line at a signal-to-noise of 6 for multiple (2) clumps. Both observations (Meier & Turner 2012) and simulations (Meijerink & Israel 2007) of SiO in nearby galaxies suggest SiO(1-0)/CO(1-0) ~ 0.05-0.1, as well as an agreement within the SiO and methanol lines (at a given transition within an order of magnitude. Thus we expect both the SiO and CH3OH fluxes to be on the order of half of that of HCO+(4-3) and thus easily detected.
SiO and CH3OH lines have been observed in other galaxies (i.e. Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with linewidths as low as 15 km/s, so we require 5 km/s spectral resolution to Nyquist sample the line.

We tune our four basebands to the SiO(8-7), CH3OH(4-3), CO(3-2), and HCO+(4-3) lines which address our main science goals. Our narrowest resulting spectral window is 1660 km/s wide which is well over the coverage we need to detect our emission lines. SiO and CH3OH have been observed in other galaxies (Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with line widths as low as 15 km/s. Even the CO(1-0) line (observed at ~400 km/s) would be Nyquist sampled in a 1660 km/s-wide band.

To enable a comparison of the distribution of molecular gas as revealed by ALMA to star clusters seen in our HST imaging, we require spatial resolutions of 0.22". The LIRG disk does not appear to extend beyond the largest recoverable scale and so we do not require the ACA.

Our goal is to map the luminous IR galaxy IRASF06399-0937 in CO(3-2), HCO+(4-3), SiO, and CH3OH. No CO(3-2) fluxes are available in the literature, so we use the published CO(1-0) flux and line width (118.1 Jy km/s, w~110 km/s; Baan et al. 2008) and an average conversion ratio quoted for LIRGs of R31~0.5 (Leech et al. 2010; Papadapolous et al. 2008) to estimate the total CO(3-2) flux. Assuming a Gaussian line, we expect peak fluxes of 4.56 mJy for CO(3-2).
If the gas distribution we are probing with ALMA is spread out (i.e. divided over ten clumps or beams) and we desire a signal-to-noise of 6, our sensitivity requirement is an rms of 76 mJy. There are also single-dish measurements of the CO(1-0) flux for this LIRG (142.0 Jy km/s and w~400 km/s; Mirabel et al. 1990). For a sample of nearby U/LIRGs, Wilson et al. (2008) found ratios of HCO+(4-3)/CO(1-0) of ~0.1-0.2 which conservatively translates to a sensitivity requirement of 3.3 mJy for detecting the HCO+(4-3) line at a signal-to-noise of 6 for multiple (2) clumps. Both observations (Meier & Turner 2012) and simulations (Meijerink & Israel 2007) of SiO in nearby galaxies suggest SiO(1-0)/CO(1-0) ~ 0.05-0.1, as well as an agreement within the SiO and methanol lines (at a given transition within an order of magnitude. Thus we expect both the SiO and CH3OH fluxes to be on the order of half of that of HCO+(4-3) and thus easily detected.
SiO and CH3OH lines have been observed in other galaxies (i.e. Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with linewidths as low as 15 km/s, so we require 5 km/s spectral resolution to Nyquist sample the line.

We tune our four basebands to the SiO(8-7), CH3OH(4-3), CO(3-2), and HCO+(4-3) lines which address our main science goals. Our narrowest resulting spectral window is 1660 km/s wide which is well over the coverage we need to detect our emission lines. SiO and CH3OH have been observed in other galaxies (Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with line widths as low as 15 km/s. Even the CO(1-0) line (observed at ~400 km/s) would be Nyquist sampled in a 1660 km/s-wide band.

To enable a comparison of the distribution of molecular gas as revealed by ALMA to star clusters seen in our HST imaging, we require spatial resolutions of 0.22". The LIRG disk does not appear to extend beyond the largest recoverable scale and so we do not require the ACA.

Our goal is to map the luminous IR galaxy NGC7592 in CO(3-2), HCO+(4-3), SiO, and CH3OH. No CO(3-2) fluxes are available in the literature, so we use the published CO(1-0) flux and line width (5.9 K km/s, w~259 km/s; Sanders et al. 1991) and an average conversion ratio quoted for LIRGs of R31~0.5 (Leech et al. 2010; Papadapolous et al. 2008), to estimate the total CO(3-2) flux. Assuming a Gaussian line, we expect peak fluxes of 3.5mJy for CO(3-2).
If the gas distribution we are probing with ALMA is spread out (i.e. divided over ten clumps or beams) and we desire a signal-to-noise of 6, our sensitivity requirement is an rms of 58.3 mJy. There are also single-dish measurements of the CO(1-0) flux for this LIRG (142.0 Jy km/s and w~400 km/s; Mirabel et al. 1990). For a sample of nearby U/LIRGs, Wilson et al. (2008) found ratios of HCO+(4-3)/CO(1-0) of ~0.1-0.2 which conservatively translates to a sensitivity requirement of 2.6 mJy for detecting the HCO+(4-3) line at a signal-to-noise of 6 for multiple (2) clumps. Both observations (Meier & Turner 2012) and simulations (Meijerink & Israel 2007) of SiO in nearby galaxies suggest SiO(1-0)/CO(1-0) ~ 0.05-0.1, as well as an agreement within the SiO and methanol lines (at a given transition within an order of magnitude. Thus we expect both the SiO and CH3OH fluxes to be on the order of half of that of HCO+(4-3) and thus easily detected.
SiO and CH3OH lines have been observed in other galaxies (i.e. Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with linewidths as low as 15 km/s, so we require 5 km/s spectral resolution to Nyquist sample the line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Local luminous infrared galaxies are dust-enshrouded, molecular gas-rich, intense starbursts that are usually inspired by major mergers. Lirgs thus provide an ideal place for an in depth look at the effects of mergers on the interstellar medium (ISM), specifically feedback from merger-driven star formation in the form of shocks. We select a sample of LIRGs that have a so-far unexplained excess of warm molecular hydrogen as revealed by Spitzer mid-IR spectroscopy. The IR data suffer from poor spatial and spectral resolution while optical observations have difficulty probing the dense and dusty ISM. ALMA provides the best tool for uncovering shocks in these dusty starbursts and for probing the shock chemistry to determine the extent, power, and dynamics of the shocked molecular gas. We propose to map these excess H2 emitters with dense molecular gas tracers CO and HCO+ to look for evidence of shocks/outflows and to determine the scale of their contribution to heating the ISM. We will also map the shock tracers SiO and methanol (CH3OH) to diagnose strength, speed, and kinematics of any observed shocks and ultimately to determine the source of the shock.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: In Cycle 2, we were awarded a high priority (top 10%, B rank) proposal to study the spatially resolved shock chemistry in four luminous infrared galaxies (LIRGs) with unusually enhanced warm H2 emission. However, the observations have not yet been completed. Thus, we resubmit the project in Cycle 3 with the following updated proposal. If the proposed observations are delivered before the close of Cycle 2, the Cycle 3 plan proposted here can be omitted.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
